comments.body: The two styles actually have a different meaning -- `export =` would mean that `require("memoize-one")` is itself a function, and `export default` means that `require("memoize-one")` is an object with a `default` property. Since the latter seems to be the case, this PR is correct.

`memoize-one` is distributed in a few formats: CommonJS, ESM, and UMD.

```
memoize-one.cjs.js
memoize-one.cjs.js.flow
memoize-one.esm.js
memoize-one.js
memoize-one.min.js
```

It then defines two entry points in [`package.json`](https://github.com/alexreardon/memoize-one/blob/d143f883ff81dba9c46f148d212337667b941a99/package.json):

-  "main": "dist/memoize-one.cjs.js",
-  "module": "dist/memoize-one.esm.js",

Since `memoize-one.esm.js` does include a `default export`, but it's not distributed under the `main` field, does it mean the change in this PR was justified and we should treat it as if it did not have a default export?
It's justified. TS doesn't use the `module` field, so only `main` matters. (And `esModuleInterop` exists as an out)

It's not just TS, it's node. We're trying to match the lowest-common-denominator usage:

```
$ node
> require('memoize-one').default
```

If that's undefined, then the module doesn't have a default export.

Other loaders may behave differently, but not everyone is guaranteed to be using those loaders. If they are, then they can turn on `esModuleInterop`.
